bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 6, 1876

div1.p: Reed relates that he is compiling statistics and writing a report for 1875.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 6, 1876
div1.p:
After spending
a good part of the day in making
out the Annual Reports for 1875,
& struggling in vain to make the
figures result as they ought to, I
find it a genuine relief to
be able to cast them all aside
& take up my quill to write
to you. I suppose, you were
never annoyed with making
out Reports & tabulating sta-
tistics, & for this, my little love,
you should be truly thank-
ful- for you have escaped
the greatest grievance of them
all- To be lost & entangled in
an inextricable maze (the language
is not half expressive,) of figures,
with not a thread to show you
the way out & no prospect of
finding one, this it is that
racks & tortures my poor brain
as nothing else- Figures, my dar-
ling, are my weakest point(&
you know I have no strong
points.) & when I once get en-
tangled, I have to succumb in
the end, & acknowledge myself con-
quered. I am told that of
all the bright & smart young
ladies, at figures, you eclipse
them all; and I know it is true.
Having aroused your curios-
ity, I leave the subject. You
said, in your last letter, that
I seemed to be given to short
epistles, recently- well, Emi-
lie precious, if you had to write
two letters, every week, & didn't
know what to say in either
one of them, I surmise that nei-
ther of them would be very leng-
thy- Now that is just my case-
I want to write, in fact would
write every day did I yield
to my wishes, but I don't know with
what to burden my pages-
Hence, my little pet, you must
not expect me to write much
every time. I did not suppose
that you would expect me to
write eight pages, every time -- I
cannot do it- You must allow
me to write a short letter
sometimes; in fact, very often-
This must needs be brief, for I
have a lame thumb, & you would
not, I know, have me make it
worse- Don't be uneasy lest I
may think more of my books
than of you- Why, bless your
little innocent heart, 'tis your
prescence & influence that
gives me the needed energy
& courage to go on with my
studies- Without that, my books
would remain on the shelf.
You & you alone guide me
& govern me-
div1.closer:
As ever, your own,
fond & devoted Walter.
